page.title: 11TIN MINING (2)
page.content:
The miners,however,were grateful to Grylls for preserving their jobs and when Grylls died 2,386 people contributed money for the purchase of a memorial arch to him at the bottom of Coinagehall Street in Helston.
Between 1840-1850 1,200-1,400 people were employed in the mine. By 1837 2,638 blocks of tin had been smelted (a block is about three hundredweight). Output sometimes reached 220 tons of block tin a month when the average price of tin was Â£83 a ton. The deepest shaft in the mine was at a depth of 266 fathoms.
In 1847 the mine was abandoned and "great distress was felt in the neighbourhood and grass grew in the streets of Helston" - an illustration of how important the mine was.
